--- In junit@y..., Scott Stirling <sstirling@m...> wrote:
> The solution would be to exclude your EJB's interface classes 
> from being
> loaded by the JUnit custom class loader by adding them to the
> excluded.properties in junit.jar.  Granted, not a very nice 
> solution unless,
> perhaps, it were easier to modify the exclusion list.  I hear 
> in JUnit 4.0
> that one idea is to make it easy to define exclusions in TestCases
> themselves.

Hi,
I was getting a ClassCastException with my EJBHome stubs and came 
across this mail. It solved this particular problem. Thanks!

Of course I have another problem. My client and EJB classes share 
some common classes. When the client makes an EJB call and the bean  
returns these common classes, I get another ClassCastException. These 
are not home stubs but just ordinary Java classes. 

You had mentioned in your solution that we need to exclude the EJB 
interface classes. Does this mean I should exclude the EJB interface 
classes *alone*. Currently I'm excluding every class in the EJB 
package from being loaded under the assumption that what is true for 
the EJB interfaces should be valid for the other classes too ... Or 
am I wrong?

Also, is this behavior specific to the JUnit 3.7 release?
Any input would be appreciated!
Thanks,
--Das
